thread.title: Marvell Technology Discloses Probe, Warns of Second-Quarter Loss
thread.title_full: Marvell Technology Discloses Probe, Warns of Second-Quarter Loss

author: morningstar.com
title: Marvell Technology Discloses Probe, Warns of Second-Quarter Loss
text:
Marvell Technology Group Ltd. disclosed Friday that it has launched an internal accounting investigation around revenue recognition practices, and the chip maker warned it would report a second-quarter loss.
Shares in the beleaguered company tumbled 20% in early trading.
In a regulatory filing, the Bermuda-based company said its audit committee is probing certain accounting and internal control matters, centered around revenue recognition issues in the second quarter and "whether senior management's operating style during the period resulted in an open flow of information and communication to set an appropriate tone for an effective control environment."
The investigation has focused on 7% to 8% of revenue recognized during the quarter that, based upon the original customer request date, would have been received and earned in the third quarter, Marvell said.
The committee's investigation so far hasn't revealed material issues, Marvell said, adding that it believes the investigation won't have a material impact on its previously issued financial statements.
The company reported a preliminary second-quarter loss of $382.4 million, or 74 cents a share, for the period ended Aug.1. That compares to a profit of $138.9 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier. Analysts anticipated a second-quarter profit of $14.8 million, or 2 cents a share, according to Thomson Reuters.
The company reported preliminary second-quarter revenue of $711 million, representing a 26% drop from last year's quarter and short of the $721.9 million analysts projected.
Preliminary second-quarter results may change as a result of the audit committee's investigation.
The "weak near-term results reflect weakness in the [hard disk drive market], though given the aforementioned investigation we don't have confidence in the reported numbers," Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Chris Caso said in an analyst note.
Given the probe and the downturn in China, Mr. Caso said Marvell is now unlikely to divest its money-losing handset businessâ€”a move some analysts have considered key to the company's strategy.
Marvell specializes in microprocessor architecture and digital-signal processing, and it makes products for the mobile and wireless industries. The company has been struggling amid lower demand in the computer and storage sectors and from a weaker global economy.
Year-to-date, the stock has erased about 27% and shares closed at $10.55 Thursday.
